sect1.title: GNOME-exe-handler
sect1.para: The gnome-exe-handler is a utility that other applications use to launch programs inside the GNOME environment. It checks to see if a file is executable, then prompts users to be sure they want to run the file. You can also run gnome-exe-handler directly from the command line. However, other applications usually invoke the utility. For example, the Nautilus file manager frequently invokes gnome-exe-handler when you double-click on a file name or icon.

Typically, an application uses gnome-exe-handler to execute a binary file in a case where the permissions of a file have not been set to allow user execution. The gnome-exe-handler first tries to determine the type of file. If it appears to be executable, gnome-exe-handler prompts the user to determine whether the user wants to start the program. If the user answers "yes", gnome-exe-handler changes the permissions to allow the user to run the program.
Executing arbitrary programs you download from the Internet can be dangerous. Be sure you understand what a program is before you permit gnome-exe-handler to run the program.
